articles.headline: Obama Invokes Newtown Dead in Pressing for New Gun Laws
articles.snippet: As President Obama gave an impassioned speech in Connecticut, Republicans on Capitol Hill were threatening to prevent a gun-control measure from even coming up for debate.
articles.abstract: As President Obama gave an impassioned speech in Connecticut, Republicans on Capitol Hill were threatening to prevent a gun-control measure from even coming up for debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — President Obama came here on Monday before a roaring, enthusiastic crowd to remember the tragedy of 20 children and 6 educators slain at Sandy Hook Elementary School and put new pressure on a recalcitrant Congress to honor them with gun-control legislation.
articles.byline: By Peter Applebome and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Wary of China, Companies Head to Cambodia
articles.snippet: Foreign manufacturers are flocking to Cambodia as a way to limit their overwhelming reliance on factories in China.
articles.abstract: Foreign manufacturers are flocking to Cambodia as a way to limit their overwhelming reliance on factories in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Tiffany & Company is quietly building a diamond-polishing factory in Cambodia, a country popularly associated more with killing fields and land mines than baubles.

articles.headline: Battle Heats Up Over Fate of Troubled Energy Buyout
articles.snippet: Energy Future Holdings may want to tie a restructuring into a neat bow, but some creditors are certain to make this a fight of junkyard dogs.
articles.abstract: Energy Future Holdings may want to tie a restructuring into a neat bow, but some creditors are certain to make this a fight of junkyard dogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest private equity buyout ever — the $45 billion deal for the Texas energy giant TXU in 2007 — has been steadily sliding toward becoming one of the biggest busts.

articles.headline: Airlines Weigh The Pounds
articles.snippet: Weight concerns airlines, mainly those with small planes like Samoa Air, which is charging fares based on a passenger’s weight. Other airlines are cutting weight, too, which saves on fuel costs.
articles.abstract: Weight concerns airlines, mainly those with small planes like Samoa Air, which is charging fares based on a passenger’s weight. Other airlines are cutting weight, too, which saves on fuel costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Probably because I’ve been at this for 14 years, people assume I have ready answers for many often-asked air travel questions, starting with, “How can I always find the lowest fare?” To this I reply reluctantly, “I have absolutely no idea.”

articles.headline: In Europe, New Protest Over Google
articles.snippet: European antitrust officials have received a formal complaint from Google’s rivals about its Android mobile operating system.
articles.abstract: European antitrust officials have received a formal complaint from Google’s rivals about its Android mobile operating system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European antitrust regulators have received a formal complaint about Google’s Android operating system for mobile devices, even as they move to the final stages of their inquiry into the company’s search practices.

articles.headline: J.C. Penney Ousts Chief of 17 Months
articles.snippet: The retailer removed Ron Johnson, the leader it brought in from Apple, and reinstalled Myron E. Ullman III.
articles.abstract: The retailer removed Ron Johnson, the leader it brought in from Apple, and reinstalled Myron E. Ullman III.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a troublesome 17-month run, Ron Johnson is out as chief executive of J. C. Penney, and with that, the most closely watched revival effort in retail in recent memory is in danger of disintegrating.

articles.headline: No Lawyer for Miles, So One Rural State Offers Pay
articles.snippet: With rural Americans increasingly underserved by legal firms, South Dakota has enacted a financial inducement that could become a model.
articles.abstract: With rural Americans increasingly underserved by legal firms, South Dakota has enacted a financial inducement that could become a model.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARTIN, S.D. — Rural Americans are increasingly without lawyers even as law school graduates are increasingly without jobs. Just 2 percent of small law practices are in rural areas, where nearly a fifth of the country lives, recent data show.

articles.headline: Teacher Knows if You’ve Done the E-Reading
articles.snippet: Nine universities are testing technology that allows them to track their students’ progress with digital textbooks.
articles.abstract: Nine universities are testing technology that allows them to track their students’ progress with digital textbooks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Several Texas A&M professors know something that generations of teachers could only hope to guess: whether students are reading their textbooks.

articles.headline: KPMG Cancels Audits Over Insider Trading Inquiry
articles.snippet: KPMG resigned as auditor for Herbalife and Skechers and withdrew audit reports after a KPMG employee was found to have given information on clients to a third party.
articles.abstract: KPMG resigned as auditor for Herbalife and Skechers and withdrew audit reports after a KPMG employee was found to have given information on clients to a third party.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Michael J. de la Merced
